subject: AI
title: Workflow Decomposition
description: Breaking complex processes into discrete, manageable steps.

hook.text: 'Automate our customer onboarding.' That's not one task ‚Äî it's twenty: verify email, check eligibility, create account, send welcome email, assign plan, trigger tutorial... Each is a separate step.

buildup.text: Workflow decomposition: break a process into individual steps where each step has a single input, performs one action, and produces one output. Each step should be independently testable.

discovery.text: The MECE principle: Mutually Exclusive (no overlap between steps), Collectively Exhaustive (all cases covered). If two steps do similar things, merge them. If a case isn't handled, add a step.

twist.text: Over-decomposition is as bad as under-decomposition. Too many tiny steps means too many API calls, too much latency, and too many failure points. Find the right granularity.

climax.text: Draw the workflow before coding it. Use a simple diagram: boxes for steps, arrows for data flow, diamonds for decisions. If you can't draw it clearly, you can't build it.

punchline.text: A complex workflow is just simple steps in the right order. Break it down.

quiz.question: What is the key principle of workflow decomposition?
options: Make as many steps as possible
Each step should have a single input, perform one action, and produce one output
Combine all steps into one large AI prompt
